thread.title: Award-winning poet Muldoon to read Oct. 29 at St. Ben's
thread.title_full: Award-winning poet Muldoon to read Oct. 29 at St. Ben's

title: Award-winning poet Muldoon to read Oct. 29 at St. Ben's
text:
Award-winning poet Muldoon to read Oct. 29 at St. Ben's TIMES STAFF REPORT 2:26 p.m. CDT October 21, 2015 Poet Paul Muldoon speaks on stage Oct. 10, 2014, during The New Yorker Festival at the SVA Theatre in New York City. (Photo: Bryan Bedder/Getty Images) 1 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
An acclaimed poet and professor will read from his work at 7 p.m. Oct. 29 at the College of St. Benedict. 
Paul Muldoon won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry in 2003 and the T.S. Eliot Prize in 1994. He teaches at Princeton University, according to a news release from St. Ben's and St. John's University. 
The Ireland native is The New Yorker's poetry editor. His latest collection of poems, "One Thousand Things Worth Knowing," has received praise as a "dazzlingly complex" book. 
In a review for The Telegraph, Charlotte Runcie said Muldoon's poetry "combines snippets of the ancients (terracotta warriors, Benedictine nuns, the life of Moses) with up-to-the-minute vernacular and freshness (mash-ups and selfies)." 
"His technical and linguistic brilliance is probably second to none," Fran Brearton said in a review for The Guardian. 
The Literary Arts Institute is presenting the Thursday event, which is free and open to the public. It will be in Room 204 of the Gorecki Center, which stands near the middle of the St. Ben's campus to the east of guest parking lot No. 5.
